image.altText: A mother and father holding their young daughter between them, smiling. They are standing on an apartment balcony.

items.synopsis: Medium- and high-density development in established suburbs is being spruiked as the solution to Australia's housing crisis. But there are still some risks.

title.children: Sean and Jane paid $720,000 for an apartment with no car parks and shared laundry. It was their path out of renting

items.synopsis: Housing costs are at record highs, and we can show you who is bearing the brunt of the crisis.

title.children: Where you sit on this chart determines your level of housing stress

image.altText: Vanessa Hudson, the incoming Qantas CEO, with model plane in foreground showing Flying Kangaroo

items.synopsis: With Alan Joyce announcing his abrupt departure from Qantas two months ahead of schedule, Vanessa Hudson is now in control of an airline with a reputation problem — and disgruntled customers say it will be tough to win them back.

title.children: New Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson faces an uphill battle to restore the public's faith as Alan Joyce departs

title.children: Anthony Albanese starts summit season talking trade ties and regional security, with China in mind

image.altText: young girl on bus.

items.synopsis: From war-torn hills and valleys, to the sheep and wheat paddocks of remote Australia, the Karen people are determined to pass down their language and traditions to the next generation.

title.children: Karen refugees keep their culture alive in rural Australia after fleeing war in Myanmar

image.altText: A woman with blue shirt and name tag sits looking up at and holding the knee of a woman who sits on a raised bed.

items.synopsis: Australia has one of the world's best healthcare systems. But senior physician Fiona Reilly argues it doesn't always work as well as it should for patients.

title.children: It only takes 11 seconds for a GP to interrupt a patient. A simple shift could change things

image.altText: A man looks on, waving his arms

items.synopsis: Spain's beleaguered football federation sacks the coach of its national women's team, Jorge Vilda, less than three weeks after he oversaw its World Cup triumph in Australia.

title.children: Spain sacks World Cup-winning women's coach as post-tournament chaos continues

image.altText: A woman's hands holding two shells, seen from above

items.synopsis: A vast collection of Indigenous artefacts kept in England for decades is being returned to the Northern Territory, ending an "emotional" years-long repatriation process.

title.children: 'The first time I saw them it made me cry': Indigenous artefacts returned after decades in English museum

image.altText: A close up of Enrique at a rally outside wearing black sunglasses and a black cap that says The War.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Former Proud Boys leader jailed for 22 years over January 6. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by North American correspondent Barbara Miller The former chairman of the far-right Proud Boys group Enrique Tarrio has been sentenced to 22 years' prison for his role in the events of January 6. Dressed in an orange jumpsuit, the 39 year-old was in court in Washington, DC to hear the sentence, the longest handed down so far in the criminal cases resulting from January 6. Tarrio addressed the court ahead of sentencing, describing what happened on January 6 as "national embarrassment" and apologised to members of Congress, the police officers who defended the Capitol and the citizens of Washington, DC. The defendant pleaded with the judge to show him mercy and broke down when talking of his family, saying he had failed them. The prosecution argued Tarrio organised street violence on a national scale, bringing together the group that entered the Capitol, instructing and leading them. In handing down the sentence Judge Timothy Kelly said what happened on January 6 damaged a precious American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power and it was going to take time to fix it.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Former Proud Boys leader sentenced to 22 years over January 6

children.content: Reporting by North American correspondent Barbara Miller
The former chairman of the far-right Proud Boys group
Enrique Tarrio
has been sentenced to 22 years' prison for his role in the events of January 6.
Dressed in an orange jumpsuit, the 39 year-old was in court in Washington, DC to hear the sentence, the
longest handed down so far
in the criminal cases resulting from January 6.

props.alt: Enrique stands with other Proud Boys dressed in black and yellow.

children.content: (AP: Noah Berger)
Tarrio addressed the court ahead of sentencing, describing what happened on January 6 as
"national embarrassment" and apologised to members of Congress
, the police officers who defended the Capitol and the citizens of Washington, DC.
The defendant pleaded with the judge to show him mercy and
broke down when talking of his family
, saying he had failed them.
The prosecution argued Tarrio
organised street violence on a national scale
, bringing together the group that entered the Capitol, instructing and leading them.
In handing down the sentence Judge Timothy Kelly said what happened on January 6
damaged a precious American tradition
of the peaceful transfer of power and it was going to take time to fix it.

image.altText: RBA governor Philip Lowe speaks at the Morgan Stanley Australia summit in Sydney

items.synopsis: The public service code of conduct sets out reasons why a Reserve Bank governor should not move to a private bank at the end of the term. But there is nothing to stop Philip Lowe doing so and — as shabby as it seems — he wouldn't be the first, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: With his last interest rates decision made, will Philip Lowe move to a private bank?

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: The latest GDP data is expected to show an annual slowdown in the Australian economy because of interest rate hikes.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Economy expected to tread water, Wall Street falls, Australian dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog, I'm Sue Lannin. A rise in oil prices has seen US stocks fall overnight on the first trading day of a holiday shortened week. The Dow Jones index fell 0.6 per cent after oil prices increased to the highest since November as Saudi Arabia and Russia extended voluntary production cuts. Bond yields jumped with the yield on the 10 year US Treasury bond rising 0.06 per cent to 4.27 per cent as investors focus on the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates. The Australian share market is expected to open lower this morning. The Australian dollar fell more than 1 per cent overnight to 63.77 US cents after the RBA kept official interest rates on hold for the third month in a row and as the greenback gained to the highest level since March. That's a ten month low. And investors are awaiting the June quarter GDP figures which will be out at 11:30 AEST. They expected to show a further annual economic slow down as interest rate rises work their way through the economy. Economists are predicting the economy expanded by 0.3 per cent over the June quarter, and by 1.8 per cent over the year. Over the first few months of the year, the economy grew by 0.2 per cent and by 2.3 per cent on an annual basis. Join us for all today's markets news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: GDP in focus, US stocks fall

children.content: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog, I'm Sue Lannin.
A rise in oil prices has seen US stocks fall overnight on the first trading day of a holiday shortened week.
The Dow Jones index fell 0.6 per cent after oil prices increased to the highest since November as Saudi Arabia and Russia extended voluntary production cuts.
Bond yields jumped with the yield on the 10 year US Treasury bond rising 0.06 per cent to 4.27 per cent as investors focus on the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates.
The Australian share market is expected to open lower this morning.

The Australian dollar fell more than 1 per cent overnight to 63.77 US cents after the RBA kept official interest rates on hold for the third month in a row and as the greenback gained to the highest level since March.
That's a ten month low.
And investors are awaiting the June quarter GDP figures which will be out at 11:30 AEST.
They expected to show a further annual economic slow down as interest rate rises work their way through the economy.
Economists are predicting the economy expanded by 0.3 per cent over the June quarter, and by 1.8 per cent over the year.
Over the first few months of the year, the economy grew by 0.2 per cent and by 2.3 per cent on an annual basis.
Join us for all today's markets news.
